problems.title: Critical Public Health Workforce Shortage and Burnout Crisis Undermines Health System Capacity
problems.description: The public health workforce is experiencing an unprecedented crisis marked by severe staffing shortages, widespread burnout, and alarming attrition rates. State and local health departments need to hire a minimum of 80,000 more full-time equivalent positions—an increase of nearly 80%—to provide adequate infrastructure and minimum public health services. One in three public health employees are considering leaving their organizations within the next year, citing inadequate pay, work overload, burnout, lack of advancement opportunities, stress, and organizational culture as primary reasons. The broader healthcare sector faces a projected shortage of up to 3.2 million workers by 2026, with registered nurse supply potentially falling short by over 78,000 positions by 2025. Burnout rates are catastrophic: 62% of nurses reported burnout during the pandemic with 30% considering permanent exit, while 93% of behavioral health workers report experiencing burnout. Nearly 40% of practicing physicians will be 65 or older within the next decade, creating massive retirement-driven gaps. In 2023, over 65,000 qualified nursing applicants were denied entry to U.S. nursing schools due to limited faculty and resources. Rural and underserved communities face the steepest shortages, threatening to widen health inequities.
problems.summary: Public health agencies face an 80% staffing shortfall while one-third of current workers consider leaving. Burnout affects over 90% of behavioral health workers and 60% of nurses, creating a self-reinforcing crisis that undermines health system capacity and worsens health disparities.

problems.title: Persistent Health Equity Gaps and Structural Barriers to Care Access for Underserved Populations
problems.description: Despite decades of awareness and nearly a century since WHO declared health a fundamental right, significant health disparities persist across the United States and globally. These disparities reflect longstanding structural and systemic inequalities rooted in historical and contemporary racism and discrimination. Nonelderly American Indian/Alaska Native, Black, Hispanic, and Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander individuals are significantly more likely to be uninsured than their White counterparts, despite gains since the Affordable Care Act. Formerly redlined neighborhoods have poverty rates nearly 4 times higher and uninsurance rates of 18% compared to 6% in historically favored areas. The Health Insurance Disparities Index reveals worsening disparities from 2017-2022, particularly during and after the COVID-19 pandemic. Structural barriers include low density of healthcare providers in underserved areas, decreasing primary care in rural regions, poor transportation infrastructure, inadequate broadband access for telehealth, and persistent coverage gaps. Mental healthcare disparities are especially severe among low-income populations. Recent policy changes including new work requirements for Medicaid threaten to further reduce coverage for vulnerable populations, while the digital health divide exacerbates existing inequities.
problems.summary: Health disparities based on race, income, and geography persist and worsened during COVID-19. Structural barriers including provider shortages, insurance gaps, transportation, and digital access create systematic differences in health outcomes between advantaged and disadvantaged populations.
